newsitem.title: USA: BEFORE THE BELL - Boeing, McDonnell surge.
newsitem.headline: BEFORE THE BELL - Boeing, McDonnell surge.

text.p: Shares of Boeing Co and McDonnell Douglas Corp jumped in the U.S. pre-open after the two companies agreed to merge in a $13.3 billion deal that would create the world's largest commercial jet maker.

Boeing surged to 103-1/2 from Friday's 96-3/4 close while McDonnell traded at 65-1/8 from Friday's 52 finish, traders said. They said Lockheed Martin Corp was not trading in the pre-open. That stock ended at 86 on Friday.
The deal, which was announced on Sunday, came less that a year after previous merger talks between Boeing and McDonnell had fallen apart.
"They had talked awhile ago but people thought it was over and done with," said one trader.

Traders saw no activity in the pre-open with Continental Airlines Inc shares, but expected a weaker start. Continental chairman Gordon Bethune told employees in a telephone message taped Friday that the company was no longer holding discussions with any airlines.
The executive did not mention Delta Air Lines Inc which was rumored to have been in exploratory merger talks with Continental. Traders also saw no trading in the pre-open for Delta.
Continental class B shares ended Friday at 27-5/8.
